Lil Wayne, born Dwayne Michael Carter Jr. on December 27, 1982, in New Orleans, Louisiana, is a prolific American rapper, songwriter, and record producer, widely regarded as one of the most influential figures in the rap and hip-hop industry.

Born into a family deeply rooted in music, Lil Wayne started performing at a young age, inspired by his father's love for jazz and blues. By the age of 12, he was writing and recording his own music. He later changed his stage name to "Lil Wayne" to create a distinct identity for himself.

In 1998, Lil Wayne released his debut album, "Tha Block Is Hot," which showcased his talent as a rapper and earned him a loyal fan base. The success of the album led to a record deal with Cash Money Records, a record label founded by his father, Birdman, and his uncle, Ronald "Slim" Williams.

Over the years, Lil Wayne has released numerous critically acclaimed and commercially successful albums, such as "Lights Out" (2000), "Tha Carter" (2005), and the multi-platinum hit "Tha Carter III" (2008). His unique style of delivery and storytelling through music have earned him numerous awards and honors.

Lil Wayne is also known for his collaborations with other artists, which have resulted in chart-topping hits, such as "Lollipop" (2008) with Lil' Mama, and "International Players Anthem (I Choose You)" (2011) with Young Money. Throughout his career, Lil Wayne has faced personal struggles, including legal issues and health problems. Despite these challenges, he has continued to produce music, and his latest album, "Tha Carter V," was released in 2018.
